commit_message:
Modify RPM lists for RHEL6

Modifications to the RPM list to make devstack work on RHEL6.  Makes
various packages only install on Fedora distros; generally letting pip
install the missing dependencies on RHEL.

Additionally the Qpid package name is different in RHEL6 to Fedora.
Also a small re-write of the config file is required to avoid
authenication issues.

Change-Id: If497099d27aa9cd80e1c1cee1aff2ed6b076d309

commit_message:
Move auth_token config to .conf, key cache directories

auth_token configuration can now be read from the conf files
rather than the paste.ini files.

A key cache directory has been created for each of the 3 API services
under /var/cache/heat

This is the devstack change relating to
Heat Blueprint: keystone-middleware

This is related to this committed change:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26351/

Devstack users will find Heat to be broken until this corresponding change
is approved.

Change-Id: If6f77f86a3eeb08a58b516725bd806e39ccedb50

We don't import mim at the top level file anymore, so there's no way to

commit_message:
Fix require_map_reduce mim import

We don't import mim at the top level file anymore, so there's no way to
check against mim.Connection. And we can't blindly check for conn.conn since
other drivers like SQLAlchemy don't have a conn attributes. That's not part
of the Connection interface.

Change-Id: I25ea31d10bb7a28296676fbec4d2ad015d082cf1
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/12/27012/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: from ming import mim if hasattr(conn, "conn") and isinstance(conn.conn, mim.Connection): import nose raise nose.SkipTest('requires spidermonkey') except ImportError: raise nose.SkipTest('requires mim')
deleted_lines: if isinstance(conn.conn, mim.Connection): raise nose.SkipTest('requires spidermonkey')

Fixes bug #1121605

This patch replacest the nvp_controller_connection configuration option
with a set of options more intutitive to user which also avoid
repetitions in ini files.

In order to simplify the configuration of the plugin, this patch also
removes named clusters. As the plugin supports a single cluster at
the moment, this can be simply specified in the [DEFAULT] configuration
section.

Also, this patch restrucures nvp_cluster.NvpCluster so that per-cluster
configuration options are not store anymore multiple times.

Change-Id: Id5f84220122d7c5f3239e3333cb772247d1ed05e

In order to simplify the configuration of the plugin, this patch also
removes named clusters. As the plugin supports a single cluster at
the moment, this can be simply specified in the [DEFAULT] configuration
section.

Also, this patch restrucures nvp_cluster.NvpCluster so that per-cluster
configuration options are not store anymore multiple times.

Change-Id: Id5f84220122d7c5f3239e3333cb772247d1ed05e
'}]
commit_message:
Simplify NVP plugin configuration

Fixes bug #1121605

This patch replacest the nvp_controller_connection configuration option
with a set of options more intutitive to user which also avoid
repetitions in ini files.

In order to simplify the configuration of the plugin, this patch also
removes named clusters. As the plugin supports a single cluster at
the moment, this can be simply specified in the [DEFAULT] configuration
section.

Also, this patch restrucures nvp_cluster.NvpCluster so that per-cluster
configuration options are not store anymore multiple times.

Change-Id: Id5f84220122d7c5f3239e3333cb772247d1ed05e

commit_message:
Don't print the empty table on list operations.

Changes to strutils.safe_encode cause the empty
table to be printed out when no objects are actually
retrieved.

This patch just adds a check of the object list length
before calling strutils.safe_encode, if the length is NOT
> 0 we just return like we used to.

Change-Id: I57930b5210c975baa7c4510fcf82b17157e17788
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/56/27156/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: print strutils.safe_encode(pt.get_string(sortby=fields[0]))

commit_message:
Mark LDAP password and admin_token secret

Add secret=True to LDAP password and admin_token
of keystone configuration.

Fix bug #1172195

Change-Id: I8ef7f705e3f6b374ff427c20eb761892d5146a75

commit_message:
Adding test_max_image_meta_exceed_limit

A negative test which verifies that server creation
with exceeding of absolute limit maxImageMeta is impossible

Change-Id: Iac3604fcb12a77a41cf822eeee2b9cd0ce2a0178
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/09/27109/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from tempest import exceptions from tempest.test import attr @attr(type='negative') def test_max_image_meta_exceed_limit(self): """ Negative test: We should not create vm with image meta over maxImageMeta limit """ # Get max limit value max_meta = self.client.get_specific_absolute_limit('maxImageMeta') #Create server should fail, since we are passing > metadata Limit! max_meta_data = int(max_meta) + 1 meta_data = {} for xx in range(max_meta_data): meta_data[str(xx)] = str(xx) self.assertRaises(exceptions.OverLimit, self.server_client.create_server, name='test', meta=meta_data, flavor_ref='84', image_ref='9e6a2e3b-1601-42a5-985f-c3a2f93a5ec3') # Verify that vm has not created list_resp = self.server_client.list_servers() self.assertEquals([], list_resp[1]['servers'])

commit_message:
Remove skips in test server rescue

* Remove skips test_rescued_vm_add_remove_security_group
* Fixes two issues
    1. In remove_security_group pass self.sg_name instead of sg_id which was
        failing earlier.
    2. Before executing unrescue server operation, the server status seems to
       be active hence the bug 1126257. So adding a rescue operation at the
       start of the test to fix the bug

Fixes bug 1126257

Change-Id: Ie79b94b9cde0f35bb4ea5955bc284139d85123cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/69/27269/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: hypervisor-list use policy
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-04-16 20:22:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1473eca4cba37cc9ecda67854b90c7536c920320', 'message': "hypervisor-list use policy

Because the DB function requires admin context, if you set a policy
for the hypervisor-list function (compute_extension:hypervisors) to not
require admin the user must still be an admin.

If you set the policy to not require admin for hypervisor-list then
non-admin users should be able to run hypervisor-list.

This change makes it so that the administrator can set the policy
to non-admin if that's appropriate for their setup.

Change-Id: I8e09c17405d3b3e356acbe863a62f87c00346d4f
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-04-16 21:08:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b886ac46831d5598070c0c985b9828f44cb61490', 'message': "hypervisor-list use policy

Because the DB function requires admin context, if you set a policy
for the hypervisor-list function (compute_extension:hypervisors) to not
require admin the user must still be an admin.

If you set the policy to not require admin for hypervisor-list then
non-admin users should be able to run hypervisor-list.

commit_message:
hypervisor-list use policy

Because the DB function requires admin context, if you set a policy
for the hypervisor-list function (compute_extension:hypervisors) to not
require admin the user must still be an admin.

If you set the policy to not require admin for hypervisor-list then
non-admin users should be able to run hypervisor-list.

This change makes it so that the administrator can set the policy
to non-admin if that's appropriate for their setup.

Change-Id: I8e09c17405d3b3e356acbe863a62f87c00346d4f

commit_message:
allow policy for host-describe

The implementation for host-describe requires that the user is an
administrator and the policy setting for compute_extension:hosts
wasn't applied.

An administrator should be able to set the policy so that
non-administrators can do host-describe if that's appropriate for
their environment.

This changes the implementation so that the compute_extension:hosts
policy applies to host-describe so that non-admins can do
host-describe if that's how the policy is configured.

Change-Id: Ifbea8dff4a29821c5919c1499db18c09e685db8e

commit_message:
host-list use policy

Because the DB function requires an admin context, if you set a
policy for the host-list function (compute_extension:hosts) to not
require admin the user must still be an admin.

If you set the policy to not require admin for host-list then non-
admin users should be able to run host-list.

This change makes it so that the administrator can set the policy
to non-admin if that's appropriate for their setup.

Fixes bug 1168488

Change-Id: I1d2e5908deefa4445ed010485e245c7cd2bac63a

commit_message:
Fix to enable negative test image_invalid_metadata

Remove skips in test_images_oneserver

* Remove skip test_create_image_specify_invalid_metadata
* Fix assertRaises bug to match against exceptions.BadRequest instead
  of exceptions.OverLimit which was causing this test case to fail.

Fixes bug 1005423

Change-Id: I877122880085d1fd69abe1d6d5b730701084c4a9

commit_message:
Add compute keypair commands

Add create, delete, list, show keypair commands

Part of blueprint nova-client

Change-Id: Ieba00d3b3e3a326f875c01ac2a2b9bbd036cd7c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/95/26895/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2013 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # """Keypair action implementations""" import logging import os import sys from cliff import command from cliff import lister from cliff import show from openstackclient.common import exceptions from openstackclient.common import utils class CreateKeypair(show.ShowOne): """Create keypair command""" api = "compute" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + '.CreateKeypair') def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(CreateKeypair, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument( 'name', metavar='<name>', help='New keypair name', ) parser.add_argument( '--public-key', metavar='<file>', help='Filename for public key to add', ) return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug('take_action(%s)' % parsed_args) compute_client = self.app.client_manager.compute public_key = parsed_args.public_key if public_key: try: with open(os.path.expanduser(parsed_args.public_key)) as p: public_key = p.read() except IOError as e: raise exceptions.CommandError( "Key file %s not found: %s" % (parsed_args.public_key, e)) keypair = compute_client.keypairs.create( parsed_args.name, public_key=public_key, ) # NOTE(dtroyer): how do we want to handle the display of the private # key when it needs to be communicated back to the user # For now, duplicate nova keypair-add command output info = {} if public_key: info.update(keypair._info) del info['public_key'] return zip(*sorted(info.iteritems())) else: sys.stdout.write(keypair.private_key) return ({}, {}) class DeleteKeypair(command.Command): """Delete keypair command""" api = "compute" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + '.DeleteKeypair') def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(DeleteKeypair, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument( 'name', metavar='<name>', help='Name of keypair to delete', ) return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug('take_action(%s)' % parsed_args) compute_client = self.app.client_manager.compute compute_client.keypairs.delete(parsed_args.name) return class ListKeypair(lister.Lister): """List keypair command""" api = "compute" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + ".ListKeypair") def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug("take_action(%s)" % parsed_args) compute_client = self.app.client_manager.compute columns = ( "Name", "Fingerprint" ) data = compute_client.keypairs.list() return (columns, (utils.get_item_properties( s, columns, ) for s in data)) class ShowKeypair(show.ShowOne): """Show keypair command""" api = 'compute' log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + '.ShowKeypair') def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(ShowKeypair, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument( 'name', metavar='<name>', help='Name of keypair to display', ) parser.add_argument( '--public-key', action='store_true', default=False, help='Include public key in output', ) return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug('take_action(%s)' % parsed_args) compute_client = self.app.client_manager.compute keypair = utils.find_resource(compute_client.keypairs, parsed_args.name) info = {} info.update(keypair._info['keypair']) if not parsed_args.public_key: del info['public_key'] return zip(*sorted(info.iteritems())) else: # NOTE(dtroyer): a way to get the public key in a similar form # as the private key in the create command sys.stdout.write(keypair.public_key) return ({}, {})

commit_message:
Add fixed-ip and floating-ip commands

Adds:
* fixed-ip commands: add, remove
* floating-ip commands: add, create, delete, list, remove
* floating-ip-poo command: list

Also uses NAME_ATTR in the Resource class if present to determine
the attribute to be used for searching in utils.find_resource()

Change-Id: Ifd8fa60f880fc4050dea182ac24553cc2c4bff15
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/30/26930/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: return manager.find(name=name_or_id)

commit_message:
Make CLI tests python2.6 compatible

- adds setUpClass method to tempest.test.BaseTestCase
  to provide it instead of unittest.TestCase
- adds replacement for subprocess.check_output and CalledProcessError
- also ensures closing of devnull provided to check_output

Change-Id: I90382f8553baabc592a2bf7008d591d83f89f416

commit_message:
Adds examples of CLI and API queries to the V2 documentation.

This patch includes additional reST-formatted text that will add new/expanded examples of v2 API use to the existing documentation.
Fixes: bug #1160929

Change-Id: I4ea132f83ce68ed5dc4b92d15a9cc650da46a114
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/06/27506/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ceilometer --debug --os-username <username_here> --os-password <password_here> --os-auth-url http://localhost:5000/v2.0/ --os-tenant-name admin meter-list A sampling of CLI commands across the OpenStack services: .. note:: The *username*, *password*, and *tenant-name* options are required to be present in these commands or specified via environment variables. Note that the in-line commands will override the environment variables. Examples:: $ ceilometer --os-username admin --os-password password --os-tenant-name admin project-list $ nova net-list $ glance --os-tenant-name service image-list $ keystone endpoint-list $ keystone --os-username admin service-listHere’s a sampling of Ceilometer API calls to try (Note that the default port for the Ceilometer API server is 8777): $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<insert_token_here>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/meters" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<inserttokenhere>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/resources" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<inserttokenhere>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/meters/disk.root.size" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<inserttokenhere>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/meters/instance?q.field=metadata.event_type&q.value=compute.instance.delete.start" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<inserttokenhere>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/meters/disk.root.size?q.field=vcpus&q.op=lt&q.value=0" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<inserttokenhere>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/meters/instance?q.field=metadata.event_type&q.value=compute.instance.exists" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:token_id' -H 'Content-Type:application/json' -d '{"q":[{"field": "timestamp","op": "ge","value":"2013-04-01T13:34:17"}]}' http://localhost:8777/v2/meters
deleted_lines: ceilometer --debug --os-username <username_here> --os-password <password_here> --os-auth-url http://localhost:5000/v2.0/ --os-tenant-name admin meter-list A sampling of CLI commands across the OpenStack services:: $ ceilometer --os-username admin --os-password password --os-tenant-name admin project-list $ nova --os-username nova --os-password password --os-tenant-name service net-list $ glance --os-username glance --os-password password --os-tenant-name service image-list $ keystone --os-username admin --os-password password --os-tenant-name admin endpoint-list $ keystone --os-username admin --os-tenant-name admin service-list (Note: use the --debug option to see the verbose details of the call)Here’s a sampling of Ceilometer API calls to try (Note that the ceilometer API server sits on port 8777): $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<insert_token_here>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/meters" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<inserttokenhere>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/resources" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<inserttokenhere>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/meters/disk.root.size" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<inserttokenhere>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/meters/instance?q.field=metadata.event_type&q.value=compute.instance.delete.start" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<inserttokenhere>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/meters/disk.root.size?q.field=vcpus&q.op=lt&q.value=0" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:<inserttokenhere>' "http://localhost:8777/v2/meters/instance?q.field=metadata.event_type&q.value=compute.instance.exists" $ curl -X GET -H 'X-Auth-Token:token_id' -H 'Content-Type:application/json' -d '{"q":[{"field": "timestamp","op": "ge","value":"2013-04-01T13:34:17"}]}' http://localhost:8777/v2/meters

commit_message:
Fix bug in db.instance_type_destroy

Fix db.instance_type_destroy()
Corresponding instance_type_projects weren't deleted

Fix db.instance_type_acces_get_by_flavor_id method
Return [] list if there is no such instance_type
instead of AttributeError

Fixes bug 1172153

Change-Id: Ib1a9a23aa6e26711c198bf4a5059797044c44426

commit_message:
Move get_backdoor_port to base rpc API.

Each service implemented the get_backdoor_port method individually.  This
patch moves the implementation of this method to the base rpc API
instead, and removes the now unnecessary code from each of the services.
The server side method was left on all of the managers for rpc backwards
copmatibility.  They can be removed on the next major rpc version bump
of those APIs.

Part of blueprint base-rpc-api.

Change-Id: Ia8838fafd80eb86a1c2d66f5e97370042d8d8c53

commit_message:
Deprecate conductor ping method.

Deprecate the ping() method of the conductor API in favor of the one
that comes with the base rpc API.

Part of blueprint base-rpc-api.

Change-Id: Iea46b7f6ce70f4919d0121433af2fd64d6346941

commit_message:
Adds image `create` and `delete` functionality.

We use the V1 API for `create` since it does not
yet exist in the V2 API in glanceclient.

For blueprint glance-client.

Change-Id: Ifa819c14f6a013f4530d16247a671e5a1c740a28
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/20/26520/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class DeleteImage(command.Command): """Delete image command""" api = "image" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + ".DeleteImage") def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(DeleteImage, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument( "id", metavar="<image_id>", help="ID of image to delete.") return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug("take_action(%s)" % parsed_args) image_client = self.app.client_manager.image image_client.images.delete(parsed_args.id)

commit_message:
Functional tests use a clean cached db that is only created once.

This eliminates the need for 'glance-manage db_sync' to be called
once (and often twice) for every test.  db_sync is an expensive
operation because it must walk through ever database migration.
With this patch, the first time the db is created it is cached
before it is used.  Instead of creating the db in future tests
the cached file is copied.  An atexit() function is used to clean
up the file when the tests are complete.

fixes bug: 1172475
blueprint: refactoring-better-faster-stronger-functional-tests

Change-Id: I96e35c640256bf27ff17da0b5f558bda02906a07

added_lines: import atexitimport tempfile glance_db_env = 'GLANCE_DB_TEST_SQLITE_FILE' if glance_db_env in os.environ: db_location = os.environ[glance_db_env] os.system('cp %s %s/tests.sqlite' % (db_location, self.test_dir)) else: cmd = ('bin/glance-manage --config-file %s db_sync' % conf_filepath) execute(cmd, no_venv=self.no_venv, exec_env=self.exec_env, expect_exit=True) (osf, db_location) = tempfile.mkstemp() os.close(osf) os.system('cp %s/tests.sqlite %s' % (self.test_dir, db_location)) os.environ[glance_db_env] = db_location def _delete_cached_db(): try: os.remove(os.environ[glance_db_env]) except: pass atexit.register(_delete_cached_db)

commit_message:
Set the port of S3_URL to 8080 with swift3 enabled

Fixes: bug #1171608
The value of the port defaults to 3333 which is the
default for nova-objectstore.

Change-Id: If87df6a765bcfc4d467628411dceec72d5af412e

commit_message:
Read metadata from local heat-cfntools cache

Heat writes to /var/lib/heat-cfntools/cfn-init-data , and heat-cfntools
writes the last metadata it read to
/var/cache/heat-cfntools/last_metadata. We expect to run on first boot,
which is why we need the heat version. Then we also expect to run after
cfn-hup notices changes, so that is where the last_metadata comes from.

Change-Id: I781c74a10b419f84c6983ed2b4d54b47bfa7b605

commit_message:
Make main() return rather than call sys.exit

Fixes tests not all being run and also makes main() more directly
testable. Also adding tests for log messages when main() is called.
Finally adding argparse to requirements.txt to fix python 2.6

Change-Id: I7f152c9aa1e99d0fd3d763871c96cf60840e3ff7

commit_message:
Add an rpc API common to all services.

This patch adds an rpc API that is exposed by all services.  The methods
in this API exist in their own namespace and are versioned independently
of the main API for the service.

The first method for this API is a simple ping() method.  This method
exists in the conductor rpc API already, and could be more generally
useful.  Other methods will be added in later patches.

The base rpc API will be exposed from all services automatically unless
they override the create_rpc_dispatcher method in the base manager
class.  All services need to pass a service_name into the base manager
constructor.  Some services already did this, but now it's needed for
all of them.

Implements blueprint base-rpc-api.

Change-Id: I02ab1970578bc53ba26461b533d06d1055c2d88e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/41/26541/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.common import base as baseapifrom nova.openstack.common.rpc import dispatcher as rpc_dispatcher def create_rpc_dispatcher(self): base = baseapi.BaseRPCAPI('compute') return rpc_dispatcher.RpcDispatcher([self, base])

commit_message:
Fix powervm driver resize instance error

During a resize operation in powervm, the logical volume
of the instance will be copied and compressed to a file.
Current logic decompresses it twice before copying this file
to a new volume which will cause the new instance to not
boot properly.

Fixes bug #1169848

Change-Id: I91f536919511aafbf7dbe14abbee48dbceb189b2

commit_message:
Fix NameError: name '_' is not defined

During running unit tests, I get this error:
  File "/var/lib/openstack-nova-test/nova/cells/rpcapi.py", line 27, in <module>
     from nova import exception
  File "/var/lib/openstack-nova-test/nova/exception.py", line 123, in <module>
     class NovaException(Exception):
  File "/var/lib/openstack-nova-test/nova/exception.py", line 131, in NovaException
     message = _("An unknown exception occurred.")
  NameError: name '_' is not defined

Change-Id: I6c75e8241675895c1bd35baa48d5383c726fe585

commit_message:
Ceilometer configuration.rst file not using right param names for logging

configuration.rst file lists all the configuration parameters for ceilometer
configuration. However, for logging, these parameter names should be log_dir
and log_file, but currently it is logdir and logfile.

The table also misses log_config.

There should be a link in configuration.rst file to point a user to the
sample configuration file.

Change-Id: Ic96f303ee7e30faf23c0a6433af5cb5111d35616
fixes: bug #1171905

commit_message:
Makes a book file root for the block storage guide.

Preparation for an RC candidate for grizzly.

Adds some chunking instructions.

Change-Id: If2ae175a1a4e41d3fd95032dcee3e8c8986192d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/96/27496/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <book xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xml:id="bk_block-storage-trunk"> <xi:include href="block-storage-overview.xml" /> </book>
deleted_lines: <chapter xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xml:id="ch_volumes"> <para>There are a number of concepts and ideas that are helpful in understanding administration of the OpenStack Block Storage service. There are a number of choices in terms of configuring the Block Storage service in OpenStack, but the bulk of the options come down to two choices, single node or multi-node install. You can read a longer discussion about storage decisions in the <link xlink:href="../openstack-ops/content/storage_decision.html">OpenStack Operations Guide</link>.</para> <para>The OpenStack Block Storage service works via the interaction of a series of daemon processes named cinder-* that reside persistently on the host machine or machines. The binaries can all be run from a single node, or spread across multiple nodes. They can also be run on the same node as other OpenStack services.</para> <para>The current services available in OpenStack Block Storage are:</para> <para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>cinder-api - The cinder-api service is a WSGI app that authenticates and routes requests throughout the Block Storage system. It supports the OpenStack API's only, although there is a translation that can be done via Nova's EC2 interface which calls in to the cinderclient.</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> </para> <para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para> cinder-scheduler - The cinder-scheduler is responsible for scheduling/routing requests to the appropriate volume service. As of Grizzly; depending upon your configuration this may be simple round-robin scheduling to the running volume services, or it can be more sophisticated through the use of the Filter Scheduler. The Filter Scheduler is the default in Grizzly and enables filter on things like Capacity, Availability Zone, Volume Types and Capabilities as well as custom filters.</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> </para> <para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>cinder-volume - The cinder-volume service is responsible for managing Block Storage devices, specifically the back-end devices themselves.</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> </para> <para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para> cinder-backup - The cinder-backup service provides a means to back up a Cinder Volume to OpenStack Object Store (SWIFT). </para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> </para> <section xml:id="managing-volumes"> <title>Managing Volumes</title> <para>Cinder is the OpenStack service that allows you to give extra block level storage to your OpenStack Compute instances. You may recognize this as a similar offering from Amazon EC2 known as Elastic Block Storage (EBS). The default Cinder implementation is an iSCSI solution that employs the use of Logical Volume Manager (LVM) for Linux. Note that a volume may only be attached to one instance at a time. This is not a ‘shared storage’ solution like a SAN of NFS on which multiple servers can attach to. It's also important to note that Cinder also includes a number of drivers to allow you to use a number of other vendor's back-end storage devices in addition to or instead of the base LVM implementation.</para> <para>Here is brief walk-through of a simple create/attach sequence, keep in mind this requires proper configuration of both OpenStack Compute via <filename>cinder.conf</filename> and OpenStack Block Storage via <filename>cinder.conf</filename>.</para> <orderedlist> <listitem> <para>The volume is created via <command>cinder create</command>; which creates an LV into the volume group (VG) "cinder-volumes" </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>The volume is attached to an instance via <command>nova volume-attach</command>; which creates a unique iSCSI IQN that will be exposed to the compute node </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>The compute node which run the concerned instance has now an active ISCSI session; and a new local storage (usually a /dev/sdX disk) </para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>libvirt uses that local storage as a storage for the instance; the instance get a new disk (usually a /dev/vdX disk) </para> </listitem> </orderedlist> <xi:include href="troubleshoot-cinder.xml"/> <xi:include href="multi_backend.xml"/> </section> <section xml:id="volume-drivers"> <title>Volume drivers</title> <para>The default cinder-volume behaviour can be altered by using different volume drivers that are included in Cinder repository. To set volume driver, use <literal>volume_driver</literal> flag. The default is as follows:</para> <programlisting> volume_driver=cinder.volume.driver.ISCSIDriver iscsi_helper=tgtadm </programlisting> <xi:include href="drivers/ceph-rbd-volume-driver.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/emc-volume-driver.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/glusterfs-driver.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/hp-3par-driver.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/hp-lefthand-driver.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/huawei-storage-driver.xml"/> <xi:include href="drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/netapp-volume-driver.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/nexenta-volume-driver.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/nfs-volume-driver.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/xenapi-nfs.xml" /> <xi:include href="drivers/xen-sm-driver.xml" /> </section> </chapter>

subject: Translate NoMoreFloatingIps exception
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-04-17 03:38:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e13aa6d7919342e216f428d4fe8e5694ca28547c', 'message': 'Translate NoMoreFloatingIps exception

When the pool of floating ips is exhausted the NoMoreFloatingIps exception
is raised but not handled properly in the floating ips extension resulting
in the exception propagating further up an causing a stack trace to be logged.

This change translates the exception explicitly into a HTTPNotFound, preserving the current
REST API behaviour. It fixes a bug where the pool name was not correctly inserted into
the message returned if allocation from a specific pool was requested.

Fixes bug 1169811

Part of blueprint no-stacktraces-in-logs

Change-Id: I8f35d25d065bb1fa709cff6f59841ac8c86658bd
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-04-18 03:35:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/bf1fe593f389e6d4f5090c0203606f55bc018d81', 'message': 'Translate NoMoreFloatingIps exception

When the pool of floating ips is exhausted the NoMoreFloatingIps exception
is raised but not handled properly in the floating ips extension resulting
in the exception propagating further up and causing a stack trace to be logged.

This change translates the exception explicitly into a HTTPNotFound, preserving the current
REST API behaviour. It fixes a bug where the pool name was not correctly inserted into
the message returned if allocation from a specific pool was requested.

Fixes bug 1169811

Part of blueprint no-stacktraces-in-logs

Change-Id: I8f35d25d065bb1fa709cff6f59841ac8c86658bd
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2013-04-18 04:52:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/04e5fcafde17a23acb2d4b4157e9f18b20874eb4', 'message': 'Translate NoMoreFloatingIps exception

When the pool of floating ips is exhausted the NoMoreFloatingIps exception
is raised but not handled properly in the floating ips extension resulting
in the exception propagating further up and causing a stack trace to be logged.

This change translates the exception explicitly into a HTTPNotFound, preserving the current
REST API behaviour. It fixes a bug where the pool name was not correctly inserted into
the message returned if allocation from a specific pool was requested.

commit_message:
Translate NoMoreFloatingIps exception

When the pool of floating ips is exhausted the NoMoreFloatingIps exception
is raised but not handled properly in the floating ips extension resulting
in the exception propagating further up and causing a stack trace to be logged.

This change translates the exception explicitly into a HTTPNotFound, preserving the current
REST API behaviour. It fixes a bug where the pool name was not correctly inserted into
the message returned if allocation from a specific pool was requested.

Fixes bug 1169811

Part of blueprint no-stacktraces-in-logs

Change-Id: I8f35d25d065bb1fa709cff6f59841ac8c86658bd

commit_message:
Remove deprecated features

When running in httpd, Django complains about deprecations.
Settings also contained some code to be removed in H relase.

Fixes bug 1172222

Change-Id: I17d7e2e7c23fd53fadf2a62c0568f61704bdf0b3

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-04-25 06:15:16.000000000', 'files': ['doc/src/docbkx/openstack-compute-admin/tables/compute-nodes-nova-conf.xml', 'doc/src/docbkx/openstack-compute-admin/computeconfigure.xml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/be819e0d98066910d2576bfccdb71163b1150480', 'message': "Document image cache manager flag for compute nodes

commit_message:
Document image cache manager flag for compute nodes

In Folsom, image cache manager is disabled by default for compute nodes.
It's related to this bug : https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1078594 when we use shared storage.

For infrastructures that don't use shared storage, it's very important to change this default from 0 to a defined value.
Otherwise, you could have some issue with disk space on your compute nodes after a while.

Fix bug #1172580

Change-Id: Ib6400d0b0a40cd4eb4911e9deefef14e33f18912
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/64/27464/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Because of a <link xlink:href="https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1078594">serious issue</link> with Nova image cache management on shared storage, the image cache manager is disabled by default in Folsom. In cases where shared storage isn't in use, it is strongly advised to re-enable by setting image_cache_manager_interval = 40 in nova.conf. If you don't configure this parameter, you could have some disk space issues on your compute nodes after a while.</para>

commit_message:
Implements Radware's lbaas plugin

Change-Id: Iff5db25425d346ecda75d8587573c36e9c2517cf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/41/26741/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # # Copyright 2013 Radware LTD. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # @author: Avishay Balderman, Radware from oslo.config import cfg from quantum.plugins.common import constants from quantum.db.loadbalancer import loadbalancer_db from quantum.openstack.common import log as logging from quantum.db import api as qdbapi from quantum.plugins.common import constants from quantum.db.loadbalancer.loadbalancer_db import Vip from quantum.db.loadbalancer.loadbalancer_db import Member from quantum.db.loadbalancer.loadbalancer_db import Pool from quantum.db.loadbalancer.loadbalancer_db import HealthMonitor from radware_vdirect_client import vDirectClient LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) radware_lbaas_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('vdirect_host', help=_('Radware vdirect IP address')) ] cfg.CONF.register_opts(radware_lbaas_opts, "LBAAS_RADWARE") class RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin(loadbalancer_db.LoadBalancerPluginDb): """ Radware Alteon lbaas plugin. The common pattern of this plugin is to call the super class that will handle the persistency and forward the request to vDirect. Get operations are handled by super class """ supported_extension_aliases = ["lbaas"] def __init__(self): """ Do the initialization for the loadbalancer service plugin here. Read vDirect connectivity details and create the vDirect client """ qdbapi.register_models() self.client = vDirectClient(cfg.CONF.LBAAS_RADWARE.vdirect_host, self) def get_plugin_name(self): return constants.LOADBALANCER def get_plugin_type(self): return constants.LOADBALANCER def get_plugin_description(self): return 'Radware Alteon LoadBalancer service plugin' # Vip def create_vip(self, context, vip): """ This method creates a vip,connected pool and the members/healthmonitors that are attached to the pool """ vip['vip']['status'] = constants.PENDING_CREATE v = super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).create_vip(context, vip) extended_vip = self._populate_vip_graph(context, v) self.client.create_vip(v['pool_id'], extended_vip) return v def update_vip(self, context, id, vip): if 'status' not in vip['vip']: vip['vip']['status'] = constants.PENDING_UPDATE v = super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).update_vip(context, id, vip) self.client.update_vip(vip['vip']['pool_id'], vip) return v def delete_vip(self, context, id): vip = self.get_vip(context, id) update_status(context, Vip, id, constants.PENDING_DELETE) self.client.delete_vip(vip['pool_id'], vip) # Pool def create_pool(self, context, pool): pool['pool']['status'] = constants.PENDING_CREATE p = super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).create_pool(context, pool) # no need to activate vdirect # when a vip will be created we will take care of the pool return p def update_pool(self, context, id, pool): if 'status' not in pool['pool']: pool['pool']['status'] = constants.PENDING_UPDATE p = super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).update_pool(context, id, pool) # no point to invoke vdirect if the pool is not connected to a vip if self._get_vip_connected_to_pool(context, id): self.client.update_pool(id, pool) return p def delete_pool(self, context, id): if self._get_vip_connected_to_pool(context, id): raise loadbalancer.PoolInUse(pool_id=id) super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).delete_pool(context, id) # TODO: what about a call to vDirect ??? # Member def create_member(self, context, member): member['member']['status'] = constants.PENDING_CREATE m = super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).create_member(context, member) if self._get_vip_connected_to_pool(context, member['member'].pool_id): self.client.create_member(member['member'].pool_id, member) else: # no need to activate vdirect # when a vip will be created we will # take care of the member pass return m def update_member(self, context, id, member): if 'status' not in member['member']: member['member']['status'] = constants.PENDING_UPDATE m = super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).update_member(context, id, member) pool_id = member['member'].pool_id if self._get_vip_connected_to_pool(context, pool_id): self.client.update_member(pool_id, member) return m def delete_member(self, context, id): member = self.get_member(context, id) if self._get_vip_connected_to_pool(context, member.pool_id): update_status(context, Member, id, constants.PENDING_DELETE) self.client.delete_member(id, member) else: # member is not associated with a vip - no need to call vdirect super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).delete_member(context, id) # Pool - Health monitor def create_pool_health_monitor(self, context, health_monitor, pool_id): hm = super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).create_pool_health_monitor(context, health_monitor, pool_id) # TODO: call vdirect. If there is a failure - remove the DB entry. # when https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/1166395 # will be fixed - we will change the status self.client.create_pool_health_monitor(health_monitor, pool_id) return hm def delete_pool_health_monitor(self, context, id, pool_id): # TODO: implement pass # Health monitor def update_health_monitor(self, context, id, health_monitor): if 'status' not in health_monitor['health_monitor']: health_monitor['health_monitor']['status'] = ( constants.PENDING_UPDATE ) hm = super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).update_health_monitor( context, id, health_monitor ) with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): qry = context.session.query( loadbalancer_db.PoolMonitorAssociation ) qry = qry.filter_by(monitor_id=hm['id']) for assoc in qry.all(): if self._get_vip_connected_to_pool(context, assoc['pool_id']): # TODO: the behavior should be the same # as create_pool_health_monitor # in that if the update in the # device filas the association should be removed. # when # https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/1166395 # will be fixed - we will change the status self.client.update_health_monitor(hm, assoc['pool_id']) update_status(context, HealthMonitor, id, constants.ACTIVE) return hm def delete_health_monitor(self, context, id): update_status(context, HealthMonitor, id, constants.PENDING_DELETE) hm = self.get_health_monitor(context, id) with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): qry = context.session.query( loadbalancer_db.PoolMonitorAssociation ) qry = qry.filter_by(monitor_id=id) for assoc in qry.all(): if self._get_vip_connected_to_pool(context, assoc['pool_id']): # TODO: the behavior should be the same # as create_pool_health_monitor # in that if the update in the device fails the # association should be removed. # when # https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/1166395 # will be fixed - we will change the status self.client.delete_health_monitor(assoc['pool_id'], hm) super(RadwareLoadBalancerPlugin, self).delete_health_monitor(context, id) # Stats def stats(self, context, pool_id): #TODO: implement with vdirect configuration template pass # private def _get_vip_connected_to_pool(self, context, id): return context.session.query(Vip).filter_by(pool_id=id).first() def _populate_vip_graph(self, context, vip): """ populate the vip with: pool,members,healthmonitors """ pool = self.get_pool(context, vip['pool_id']) vip['pool'] = pool vip['members'] = [] for member_id in pool['members']: member = self.get_member(context, member_id) vip['members'].append(member) vip['health_monitors'] = [] for hm_id in pool['health_monitors']: hm = self.get_health_monitor(context, hm_id) vip['health_monitors'].append(hm) return vip

Refactor get_console_output to be a bit simpler.

We used to have the code which read a limited amount of console
data present twice in the file.

commit_message:
Radware lbaas plugin implementation

Change-Id: I377e6058268bb8ecdc4d9f4403328e6cb87b75ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/82/27082/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # # Copyright 2013 Radware LTD. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # @author: Avishay Balderman, Radware import httplib import base64 import json import time import Queue import threading import socket from quantum import context as qcontext from quantum.db.loadbalancer.loadbalancer_db import Vip from quantum.db.loadbalancer.loadbalancer_db import Member from quantum.db.loadbalancer.loadbalancer_db import Pool from quantum.db.loadbalancer.loadbalancer_db import HealthMonitor from quantum.plugins.common import constants from quantum.openstack.common import log as logging RESP_STATUS = 0 RESP_REASON = 1 RESP_STR = 2 RESP_DATA = 3 SUCCESS_CODES = range(200, 207) L2_L3_WORKFLOW_TEMPLATE_NAME = 'l2_l3_openstack_driver' WORKFLOW_TEMPLATE_NAME = 'openstack_driver' ACTIONS_TO_SKIP = ['wait_for_service'] CFG_ITEM_TO_MODEL = { 'vip': Vip, 'member': Member, 'pool': Pool, 'health_monitor': HealthMonitor } TEMPLATE_HEADER = {'Content-Type': 'application/vnd.com.radware.vdirect.' + 'template-parameters+json'} PROVISION_HEADER = {'Content-Type': 'application/vnd.com.radware.' + 'vdirect.status+json'} CREATE_SERVICE_HEADER = {'Content-Type': 'application/vnd.com.radware.' + 'vdirect.adc-service-specification+json'} #TODO: read from config SERVICE = { "haPair": True, "primary": { "capacity": { "throughput": 1000, "sslThroughput": 100, "compressionThroughput": 100, "cache": 20 }, "network": { "type": "portgroup", "portgroups": ['DATA_NETWORK'] }, "adcType": "VA", "acceptableAdc": "Exact" } } def __(response, success_codes=[202]): if response[RESP_STATUS] not in success_codes: raise Exception(str(response[RESP_STATUS]) + ':' + response[RESP_REASON] + '. Error description: ' + response[RESP_STR]) else: return response[RESP_DATA] class vDirectClient: """ Handle calls to Radware vDirect """ def __init__(self, vdirect_address, loadbalanderDB): self.restClient = vDirectRESTClient(server=vdirect_address) self.queue = Queue.Queue() self.completionHandler = OperationCompletionHander(self.queue, self.restClient, loadbalanderDB) self.completionHandler.setDaemon(True) self.completionHandler.start() def create_vip(self, pool_id, extended_vip): """ This is the main entry point of the client 1) create a WF 2) get a service or create it. In case a new one is created - we provision it and return immediately 3) create the vip """ networks = self._get_networks(extended_vip) network_to_match = {'type': 'portgroup', 'portgroups': networks} service_name = self._get_service_name(pool_id, network_to_match) self._create_workflow(pool_id, WORKFLOW_TEMPLATE_NAME) self._activate_wait_for_service(pool_id, service_name) self._update_workflow(pool_id, 'create_vip', extended_vip) def delete_vip(self, pool_id, vip): return self._update_workflow(pool_id, 'delete_vip', vip) def update_member(self, pool_id, member): return self._update_workflow(pool_id, 'update_member', member) def delete_member(self, pool_id, member): return self._update_workflow(pool_id, 'delete_member', member) def update_pool(self, pool_id, pool): return self._update_workflow(pool_id, 'update_pool', pool) def delete_pool(self, pool_id, pool): return self._update_workflow(pool_id, 'delete_pool', pool) def update_health_monitor(self, pool_id, health_monitor): return self._update_workflow(pool_id, 'update_health_monitor', health_monitor) def delete_health_monitor(self, pool_id, health_monitor): return self._update_workflow(pool_id, 'delete_health_monitor', health_monitor) #TODO: discuss with Sam hm and pool association def create_pool_health_monitor(self, pool_id, health_monitor): return self._update_workflow(pool_id, 'create_pool_health_monitor', health_monitor) def _get_networks(extended_vip): # TODO: implement pass def _create_operation(self, action, params, response): underscore_index = action.index('_') operation_type = action[:underscore_index] entity_type = action[underscore_index + 1:] return OperationAttributes(params['id'], entity_type, operation_type, response['uri']) def _update_workflow(self, pool_id, action, params): logging.debug('_update_workflow. WF id = %s action = %s params = %s' % (pool_id, action, params)) resource = '/api/workflow/%s/action?name=%s' % (pool_id, action) response = __(self.restClient.rest_call('POST', resource, {'parameters': params}, TEMPLATE_HEADER)) logging.debug('_update_workflow response: ' + str(response)) if action not in ACTIONS_TO_SKIP: oper = self._create_operation(action, params, response) logging.debug('Pushing operation %s to the queue: ' % oper) self.queue.put_nowait(oper) def _remove_workflow(self, pool_id): resource = '/api/workflow/%s' % (pool_id) __(self.restClient.rest_call('DELETE', resource, None, None), [204, 202, 404]) def _remove_service(self, service_name): resource = '/api/service/%s' % (service_name) __(self.restClient.rest_call('DELETE', resource, None, None), [202]) def _get_service_name(self, pool_id, network_to_match): service_name = self._get_available_service(network_to_match) if not service_name: logging.debug('Could not find a service for network ' + str(network_to_match) + '. About to allocate a new service.') service_name = self._create_service(pool_id, network_to_match) # TODO: l2_l3 else: logging.debug('A matching service was found for network ' + str(network_to_match) + '.') return service_name def _create_service(self, pool_id, network_to_match): """ create the service provision it (async) """ service_name = 'service_' + str(network_to_match) # 1) create the service resource = '/api/services?name=%s' % service_name service = SERVICE service['network']['portgroups'] = network_to_match response = __(self.restClient.rest_call('POST', resource, service, CREATE_SERVICE_HEADER), [201]) # 2) provision the service provision_uri = response['links']['actions']['provision'] __(self.restClient.rest_call('POST', provision_uri, None, PROVISION_HEADER)) return service_name def _activate_wait_for_service(self, pool_id, service_name): self._update_workflow(pool_id, 'wait_for_service', {'service': service_name}) def _get_available_service(self, network_to_match): # TODO: change impl from search to get by network_to_match resource = '/api/services' response = __(self.restClient.rest_call('GET', resource, None, None), [200]) for service in response: spec_url = service['links']['specification'] spec_response = __(self.restClient.rest_call('GET', spec_url, None, None), [200]) network = spec_response['primary']['network'] if network_to_match['type'] == network['type']: types = network_to_match['type'] + 's' if set(network[types]).issubset(set(network_to_match[types])): return service['name'] return None def _workflow_exists(self, pool_id): # TODO: change impl to get wf by name (pool_id) resource = '/api/workflows' response = __(self.restClient.rest_call('GET', resource, None, None), [200]) for wf in response: if pool_id == wf['name']: return True return False def _create_workflow(self, pool_id, wf_name, create_workflow_params={}): if not self._workflow_exists(pool_id): resource = '/api/workflowTemplate/%s?name=%s' % (wf_name, pool_id) create_workflow_params = {'parameters': create_workflow_params} response = __(self.restClient.rest_call('POST', resource, create_workflow_params, TEMPLATE_HEADER)) logging.debug('create_workflow response: ' + str(response)) class vDirectRESTClient: """ REST server proxy to Radware vDirect """ def __init__(self, server='localhost', port=2188, ssl=None, auth=None, timeout=5000, base_uri=''): self.server = server self.port = port self.ssl = ssl self.base_uri = base_uri self.timeout = timeout self.success_codes = SUCCESS_CODES self.auth = None if auth: self.auth = 'Basic ' + base64.encodestring(auth).strip() def rest_call(self, action, resource, data, headers): if resource.startswith('http'): uri = resource else: uri = self.base_uri + resource body = json.dumps(data) debug_params = {'server': self.server, 'port': self.port, 'ssl': self.ssl, 'action': action} logging.debug("vdirectRESTClient: server=%(server)s," " port=%(port)d, " "ssl=%(ssl)r, action=%(action)s", debug_params) if not headers: headers = {} conn = None if self.ssl: conn = httplib.HTTPSConnection( self.server, self.port, timeout=self.timeout) if conn is None: logging.error('vdirectRESTClient: Could not establish HTTPS ' 'connection') return 0, None, None, None else: conn = httplib.HTTPConnection( self.server, self.port, timeout=self.timeout) if conn is None: logging.error('vdirectRESTClient: Could not establish HTTP ' 'connection') return 0, None, None, None try: conn.request(action, uri, body, headers) response = conn.getresponse() respstr = response.read() respdata = respstr if response.status in self.success_codes: try: respdata = json.loads(respstr) except ValueError: # response was not JSON, ignore the exception pass ret = (response.status, response.reason, respstr, respdata) except (socket.timeout, socket.error) as e: logging.error('vdirectRESTClient: %(action)s failure, %(e)r', locals()) ret = 0, None, None, None conn.close() return ret class OperationAttributes: """ Holds operation attributes """ def __init__(self, entity_id, entity_type, operation_type, operation_url, object_graph=None): self.entity_id = entity_id self.entity_type = entity_type self.operation_type = operation_type self.operation_url = operation_url self.object_graph = object_graph self.creation_time = time.time() def __repr__(self): items = ("%s = %r" % (k, v) for k, v in self.__dict__.items()) return "<%s: {%s}>" % (self.__class__.__name__, ', '.join(items)) class OperationCompletionHander(threading.Thread): """ Update DB with operation status or delete the entity from DB """ def __init__(self, queue, restClient, loadbalanderDB): threading.Thread.__init__(self) self.queue = queue self.restClient = restClient self.admin_ctx = qcontext.get_admin_context() self.loadbalanderDB = loadbalanderDB def _get_db_status(self, operation, success, messages=None): """ get the db_status based on the status of the vdirect operation """ if not success: # we have a failure - log it and set the return ERROR as DB state msg = ', '.join(messages) if messages else "unknown" logging.error('Operation %s failed. Reason: %s' % (operation, msg)) return constants.ERROR if operation.operation_type in ["create", "update"]: return constants.ACTIVE elif operation.operation_type == 'delete': return None def run(self): oper = None while True: try: oper = self.queue.get() logging.debug('Operation consumed from the queue: ' + str(oper)) # check the status - if oper is done: update the db , # else push the oper again to the queue result = self.restClient.rest_call('GET', oper.operation_url, None, None) completed = result[RESP_DATA]['complete'] if completed: # operation is done - update the DB with the status success = result[RESP_DATA]['success'] seconds_until_completion = time.time() - oper.creation_time logging.debug('Operation %s is completed after %d' + ' seconds with success status: %s :' % (success, seconds_until_completion, oper)) db_status = self._get_db_status(oper, success) if db_status: if oper.object_graph: # TODO: walk over the object graph # (a Vip?) and run more updates pass else: logging.debug("About to update the DB status " + " of a %s with id %s. " + " New status is %s." % (oper.entity_type, str(oper.entity_id))) model = CFG_ITEM_TO_MODEL[oper.entity_type] self.loadbalanderDB.update_status(self.admin_ctx, model, oper.entity_id, db_status) else: logging.debug("About to delete a %s with id %s" % (oper.entity_type, str(oper.entity_id))) delete_method_name = 'delete_' + oper.entity_type method_to_call = getattr(self.loadbalanderDB, delete_method_name) method_to_call(self.admin_ctx, oper.entity_id) else: # not completed - push to the queue again logging.debug('Operation %s is not completed yet..' % oper) # queue is empty - lets take a short rest if self.queue.empty(): time.sleep(0.2) self.queue.put_nowait(oper) # send a signal to the queue that the job is done self.queue.task_done() except Exception: msg = "Exception was thrown inside OperationCompletionHander" logging.exception(msg)

commit_message:
Shares Service in Cinder.

This change adds the client side of shares service in Cinder.

Following CLI commands are supported:
    share-create        Creates new NAS storage (NFS or CIFS).
    share-delete        Deletes NAS storage.
    share-list          List all NAS shares.
    share-allow         Allow access to the share.
    share-deny          Deny access to a share.
    share-show          Show details about a NAS share.
    share-snapshot-create
                        Add a new snapshot.
    share-snapshot-delete
                        Remove a snapshot.
    share-snapshot-list
                        List all the snapshots.
    share-snapshot-show
                        Show details about a snapshot.

Change-Id: Ib49fbe6417152571a5c64a94427b9ebf2081559b

commit_message:
Add stats reporting to Nexenta Driver

Nexenta driver was never updated to report stats.
This change doesn't include support for backend_name assignment
via configs, there's some other work that will need to be
done to enable that.

Fixes bug: 1166607

Change-Id: Id9cfff24df8815a67e42393aa18fd41ac1b9e6b3

added_lines: def get_volume_stats(self, refresh=False): """Get volume status. If 'refresh' is True, run update the stats first.""" if refresh: self._update_volume_status() return self._stats def _update_volume_status(self): """Retrieve status info for Nexenta device.""" # NOTE(jdg): Aimon Bustardo was kind enough to point out the # info he had regarding Nexenta Capabilities, ideally it would # be great if somebody from Nexenta looked this over at some point KB = 1024 MB = KB ** 2 LOG.debug(_("Updating volume status")) data = {} data["volume_backend_name"] = self.__class__.__name__ data["vendor_name"] = 'Nexenta' data["driver_version"] = '1.0' data["storage_protocol"] = 'iSCSI' stats = self.nms.volume.get_child_props(FLAGS.nexenta_volume, 'health|size|used|available') total_unit = stats['size'][-1] total_amount = float(stats['size'][:-1]) free_unit = stats['available'][-1] free_amount = float(stats['available'][:-1]) if total_unit == "T": total_amount = total_amount * KB elif total_unit == "M": total_amount = total_amount / KB elif total_unit == "B": total_amount = total_amount / MB if free_unit == "T": free_amount = free_amount * KB elif free_unit == "M": free_amount = free_amount / KB elif free_unit == "B": free_amount = free_amount / MB data['total_capacity_gb'] = total_amount data['free_capacity_gb'] = free_amount data['reserved_percentage'] = 0 data['QoS_support'] = False self._stats = data

commit_message:
Send 400 error if device specification contains unexpected attributes

Bug #1171926

This patch simply enhances the validator for the 'devices' attribute
by verifying each element in the device list does not contain
unexpected attributes.

Change-Id: Id3fd182a7f711b482ad371752983264ad73b100f

commit_message:
Reorganize & split child functions into a child server

Instead of having the process launcher class be the one starting
child processes, keeping track of them, as well as having the functions
that the child process uses, it seems better to have the main process
launcher class only care about starting, tracking, and terminating child
servers and have the child functionality be separated.

Change-Id: I4b04aa2215050911bd0c873111cafc003b91d952
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/44/26044/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Modified from: http://doughellmann.com/2008/08/pymotw-signal.html SIGNALS_NAMES = {} for n in dir(signal): if n.startswith('SIG') and n.find("_") == -1: SIGNALS_NAMES[getattr(signal, n)] = str(n) signame = SIGNALS_NAMES[exc.signo] self.children = [] def remove(self, pid): matched_children = [c for c in self.children if c.pid == pid] for c in matched_children: self.children.remove(c) # NOTE(harlowja): this is becoming similar to the multiprocessing # library, maybe in the future we should just move to using that? class ChildServer(object): def __init__(self, parent_pipe, before_launch=None): self.parent_pipe = parent_pipe self.pid = None self.before_launch = before_launch def _child_process(self, server): # Setup child signal handlers differently def _sigterm(*args): signal.signal(signal.SIGTERM, signal.SIG_DFL) raise SignalExit(signal.SIGTERM) signal.signal(signal.SIGTERM, _sigterm) # Block SIGINT and let the parent send us a SIGTERM signal.signal(signal.SIGINT, signal.SIG_IGN) # Reopen the eventlet hub to make sure we don't share an epoll # fd with parent and/or siblings, which would be bad eventlet.hubs.use_hub() # Create greenthread to watch for parent to close pipe eventlet.spawn(self._pipe_watcher) # Reseed random number generator random.seed() launcher = Launcher() launcher.run_server(server) def _exit(self, status): # Can't use the regular exit due to how python # will attempt to invoke exit methods on this forked child # and the parent, which may be the same exit methods. os._exit(status) # TODO(harlowja): rework this so that child processes do not share # any common resources between the child and parent (except the # terminated pipe which is used to notify the child that the parent # is dead) so that the correct exit method can be used. def _pipe_watcher(self): # This will block (unless greened) until the write end is closed when # the parent dies unexpectedly self.parent_pipe.read() LOG.info(_('Parent process has died unexpectedly, exiting')) self._exit(1) def run(self, server): pid = os.fork() if pid != 0: # In the parent, just capture the pid. self.pid = pid return self.pid = os.getpid() if self.before_launch: self.before_launch() status = 0 try: self._child_process(server) except SignalExit as exc: signame = SIGNALS_NAMES[exc.signo] LOG.info(_('Child %s caught %s, exiting'), self.pid, signame) status = exc.code except SystemExit as exc: status = exc.code except BaseException: LOG.exception(_('Unhandled exception in child %s'), self.pid) status = 2 finally: server.stop() self._exit(status) self.children = {} def _start_child(self, server): # Any actions that need to happen before the child should start its # main server function happen here... def close_parent(): # Close write to ensure only parent has it open os.close(self.writepipe) child = ChildServer(self.readpipe, before_launch=close_parent) child.run(server) LOG.info(_('Started child %d'), child.pid) return child def launch_server(self, server): launch_wrapper = ServerWrapper(server, workers) self._launch_wrap(launch_wrapper) def _launch_wrap(self, wrap, wait_between=1): workers_needed = wrap.workers - len(wrap.children) if workers_needed <= 0: return LOG.info(_('Starting %d workers'), workers_needed) while self.running and len(wrap.children) < wrap.workers: if len(wrap.forktimes) > wrap.workers: # Limit ourselves to one process a second (over the period of # number of workers * 1 second). This will allow workers to # start up quickly but ensure we don't fork off children that # die instantly too quickly. # # Note(harlowja): we aren't tracking fork going crazy at this # point, when we likely should, basically if children fire up # and then die, we will be endless spawning children when we # should probably have some upper bound when the parent process # just gives up. if time.time() - wrap.forktimes[0] < wrap.workers: LOG.info(_('Forking too fast, sleeping')) time.sleep(wait_between) wrap.forktimes.pop(0) else: wrap.forktimes.append(time.time()) child = self._start_child(wrap) # Append the wrap object as well since this object # could be used to start many 'wrap' objects, and one child # death we need to be able to connect it back to the original # wrap object for removal self.children[child.pid] = wrap wrap.children.append(child) signame = SIGNALS_NAMES[sig] LOG.info(_('Child %(pid)d killed by signal %(signame)s'), locals()) # Find the correct wrap object, and clean it from there wrap.remove(pid) # Relaunch any workers that may have just died self._launch_wrap(wrap) signame = SIGNALS_NAMES[self.sigcaught] for pid in self.children.keys():

This will allow workers to # start up quickly but ensure we don't fork off children that # die instantly too quickly. if time.time() - wrap.forktimes[0] < wrap.workers: LOG.info(_('Forking too fast, sleeping')) time.sleep(1) wrap.forktimes.pop(0) wrap.forktimes.append(time.time()) pid = os.fork() if pid == 0: # NOTE(johannes): All exceptions are caught to ensure this # doesn't fallback into the loop spawning children. commit_message:
Avoid calling sudo in install_venv_common.py.

Updates our common venv installation routine so that it no longer
attempts to automatically install missing RPM packages via sudo
and instead just prints an error message and dies.

The primary motivation here was to avoid sudo altogether since
some people would rather not have the test suite run these sorts
of systems admin commands for them.

Change-Id: I350e5421a4dd3094217270d39547acaea0aeda3b

commit_message:
Add middleware to limit size of HTTP requests.

Adds a new RequestBodySizeLimiter middleware to guard against
really large HTTP requests. The default max request size is 112k
although this limit is configurable via the 'max_request_body_size'
config parameter.

Change-Id: I76248feed5c77f678b8a43f364d4f1e0794ab910
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/85/27285/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2012 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo.config import cfg import StringIO import webob from openstack.common.middleware import sizelimit from tests import utils CONF = cfg.CONF MAX_REQUEST_BODY_SIZE = CONF.max_request_body_size class TestLimitingReader(utils.BaseTestCase): def test_limiting_reader(self): BYTES = 1024 bytes_read = 0 data = StringIO.StringIO("*" * BYTES) for chunk in sizelimit.LimitingReader(data, BYTES): bytes_read += len(chunk) self.assertEquals(bytes_read, BYTES) bytes_read = 0 data = StringIO.StringIO("*" * BYTES) reader = sizelimit.LimitingReader(data, BYTES) byte = reader.read(1) while len(byte) != 0: bytes_read += 1 byte = reader.read(1) self.assertEquals(bytes_read, BYTES) def test_limiting_reader_fails(self): BYTES = 1024 def _consume_all_iter(): bytes_read = 0 data = StringIO.StringIO("*" * BYTES) for chunk in sizelimit.LimitingReader(data, BYTES - 1): bytes_read += len(chunk) self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPRequestEntityTooLarge, _consume_all_iter) def _consume_all_read(): bytes_read = 0 data = StringIO.StringIO("*" * BYTES) reader = sizelimit.LimitingReader(data, BYTES - 1) byte = reader.read(1) while len(byte) != 0: bytes_read += 1 byte = reader.read(1) self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPRequestEntityTooLarge, _consume_all_read) class TestRequestBodySizeLimiter(utils.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestRequestBodySizeLimiter, self).setUp() @webob.dec.wsgify() def fake_app(req): return webob.Response(req.body) self.middleware = sizelimit.RequestBodySizeLimiter(fake_app) self.request = webob.Request.blank('/', method='POST') def test_content_length_acceptable(self): self.request.headers['Content-Length'] = MAX_REQUEST_BODY_SIZE self.request.body = "0" * MAX_REQUEST_BODY_SIZE response = self.request.get_response(self.middleware) self.assertEqual(response.status_int, 200) def test_content_length_too_large(self): self.request.headers['Content-Length'] = MAX_REQUEST_BODY_SIZE + 1 self.request.body = "0" * (MAX_REQUEST_BODY_SIZE + 1) response = self.request.get_response(self.middleware) self.assertEqual(response.status_int, 413) def test_request_too_large_no_content_length(self): self.request.body = "0" * (MAX_REQUEST_BODY_SIZE + 1) self.request.headers['Content-Length'] = None response = self.request.get_response(self.middleware) self.assertEqual(response.status_int, 413)

commit_message:
Add enforcement for foreign key contraints with sqlite

Fixes bug 1171732

When creating an engine the called can indicate whether or
not to enforce the constraints for sqlite.

Change-Id: I1d5820376f60388c084afea500f807cd25541800
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/20/27320/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from sqlalchemy.interfaces import PoolListenerclass SqliteForeignKeysListener(PoolListener): """ Ensures that the foreign key constraints are enforced in SQLite. The foreign key constraints are disabled by default in SQLite, so the foreign key constraints will be enabled here for every database connection """ def connect(self, dbapi_con, con_record): dbapi_con.execute('pragma foreign_keys=ON') engine_args["listeners"] = [SqliteForeignKeysListener()]

commit_message:
Import and convert to oslo loopingcall.

Import the oslo looping call implementation (which is a copy of
nova's), delete nova's local copy, convert all users to the new
location.

It should be noted that the oslo implementation of
FixedIntervalLoopingCall measures time from the start of the
periodic task, not the end, so periodic tasks will run with a
constant frequency instead of the frequency changing depending on
how long the periodic task takes to run.

Change-Id: Ia62ce1988f5373c09146efa6b3b1d1dc094d50c4

added_lines: class TestFixedIPGetByInstance(test.TestCase): def test_fixed_ip_found(self): ctxt = context.get_admin_context() instance = db.instance_create(ctxt, {}) instance_uuid = instance['uuid'] FIXED_IP_ADDRESS = 'address' db.fixed_ip_create(ctxt, dict( instance_uuid=instance_uuid, address=FIXED_IP_ADDRESS)) ips_list = db.fixed_ip_get_by_instance(ctxt, instance_uuid) self.assertEquals(1, len(ips_list)) self.assertEquals(FIXED_IP_ADDRESS, ips_list[0].address) def test_fixed_ip_not_found__exception_should_be_raised(self): ctxt = context.get_admin_context() instance = db.instance_create(ctxt, {}) instance_uuid = instance['uuid'] self.assertRaises(exception.FixedIpNotFoundForInstance, db.fixed_ip_get_by_instance, ctxt, instance_uuid)

commit_message:
Fixes test in response to optional hostname fix

Several tests have had their behavior changed
with the client appending the default host.
With that new behavior reversed in the client,
some tests use a username that contains an @,
causing an ambiguous case for the API to parse.
Deliberately including the host in the tests
fixes this.

Fixes Bug #1171559

Change-Id: I967eb4b21d8ca3e2c2721db6f362b8dac2551346

commit_message:
Add a MAINTAINERS file

Following on from discussions at the summit, add a file which explains
the idea of oslo-core being a group of generalists and that each API
in the incubator should have a specialist maintainer.

I've made a quick stab at capturing the status of APIs where its most
obvious. I'm thinking we let people submit changes to add themselves
to the file so they're on record saying "I'll maintain this".

Change-Id: I5e67f94dc77f14849dea425dec51896fed0d07ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/79/27379/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: = Generalist Code Reviewers = Oslo has a cadre of core reviewers who have taken on a generalist role on the project. They are folks with good taste in Python code, provide constructive input in their reviews and make time to review any patches submitted to the project, irrespective of the area which a given patch targets. The current members of oslo-core are listed here: https://review.openstack.org/#/admin/groups/106,members This the group who can +2 and approve patches in oslo. However, they may choose to seek feedback from the appropriate specialist API maintainer before approving a patch if it is in any way controversial or risky. = Specialist API Maintainers = APIs in oslo-incubator are resting here temporarily until they have been cleaned up sufficiently so that we can make a commitment to backwards compatibility and release the API in a properly published library. While in oslo-incubator, an API should have one or more specialist maintainers who have taken on the following responsibilities: - Developing a roadmap for the API graduating from the incubator - Reviewing changes proposed for that API - a +1 from an API maintainer should be treated as a +2 by oslo-core members - Keeping track of which Integrated projects are using the API and helping to ensure the API meets the use cases of those projects - Ensuring that any incompatible or potentially troublesome changes are synced from oslo-incubator into the projects using the API, either by performing the sync themselves are asking that the authors of the patch perform the sync = List of API Maintainers = Each API has an entry with the following keys: M: Maintainer email address S: Status, one of the following: Maintained: Has an active maintainer Orphan: No current maintainer, feel free to step up! Obsolete: Replaced by newer code, or a dead end, or out-dated F: Wildcard patterns, relative to openstack/common/ == authutils == M: S: Orphan F: authutils.py == build == M: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com> S: Orphan F: setup.py F: version.py == cfg == M: Mark McLoughlin <markmc@redhat.com> S: Maintained F: cfgfilter.py == cliutils == M: S: Orphan F: cliutils.py == context == M: S: Obsolete F: context.py F: middleware/context.py == db == M: S: Orphan F: db/ == eventlet_backdoor == M: S: Orphan F: eventlet_backdoor.py == exception == M: S: Obsolete F: exception.py == excutils == M: S: Orphan F: excutils.py == fileutils == M: S: Orphan F: fileutils.py == fixtures == M: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com> S: Maintained F: fixture/ == gettextutils == M: Mark McLoughlin <markmc@redhat.com> S: Maintained F: gettextutils.py == importutils == M: S: Orphan F: importutils.py == jsonutils == M: S: Orphan F: jsonutils.py == local == M: S: Orphan F: local.py == lockutils == M: S: Orphan F: lockutils.py == log == M: S: Orphan F: log.py == loopingcall == M: S: Orphan F: loopingcall.py == memorycache == M: S: Orphan F: memorycache.py == network_utils == M: S: Orphan F: network_utils.py == notifier == M: S: Orphan F: notifier/ == pastedeploy == M: Mark McLoughlin <markmc@redhat.com> S: Obsolete F: pastedeploy.py == periodic_task == M: S: Orphan F: periodic_task.py == plugins == M: S: Orphan F: plugin/ == policy == M: S: Orphan F: policy.py == processutils == M: S: Orphan F: processutils.py == rootwrap == M: Thierry Carrez <thierry@openstack.org> S: Maintained F: rootwrap/ == rpc == M: Mark McLoughlin <markmc@redhat.com> M: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com> S: Maintained F: rpc/ == scheduler == M: S: Orphan F: scheduler/ == service == M: S: Orphan F: service.py == sslutils == M: S: Orphan F: sslutils.py == strutils == M: S: Orphan F: strutils.py == threadgroup == M: S: Orphan F: threadgroup.py == timeutils == M: S: Orphan F: timeutils.py == uuidutils == M: S: Orphan F: uuidutils.py == wsgi == M: S: Orphan F: wsgi.py == xmlutils == M: S: Orphan F: xmlutils.py == zmq == M: Eric Windisch <eric@cloudscaling.com> S: Maintained F:
